You Can Cook These Famous Movie Meals

Video recipes for ‘Big Night,’ ‘Chef,’ ‘Tampopo’ and other classic food porn cinema

Food has been a key part of movies since the invention of popcorn.

Films centered on food work best when they beguile you with sensual images of cuisine and its preparation; once entranced, you are easily lulled into feeling what the characters feel as they taste what you can only imagine.

But that’s the real problem with food movies: You can see, but you can’t eat.

Haven’t you wanted to savor the sauce-drenched timpano prepared by Primo (Tony Shalhoub) and Secondo (Stanley Tucci) in Big Night? Or bite into the oozing Cubano sandwich grilled by Carl (Jon Favreau) in Chef? Or slurp the ramen from Tampopo?

Fortunately, you’re not alone: People have gone out of their way to replicate the most tantalizing dishes from the best food films and figured out how you can make them at home. We’ve rounded up a few.

The New Streaming Service for Movie Lovers
A diverse selection of films curated by actors, directors and industry insiders.outtake.tribecashortlist.com

Why bother? As Primo tells his secret crush after feeding her lasagna: “To eat good food is to be close to God.”

1. Timpano from ‘Big Night’ (1996)

The massive drum-shaped pasta-based dish, sometimes called a timballo, is the centerpiece of the film’s dinner party. Much is made about the complexity of its preparation and the time it takes.

YouTube cooking show Binging With Babish took on the three-hour challenge of making one, and he’s shared it with you. It’s more than just a big-ass lasagna.

Want to see the masters make their ultimate feast? Stream Big Night on Tribeca Shortlist now.

2. Cailles en Sarcophage from ‘Babette’s Feast’ (1987)

This indescribably decadent dish—pan-roasted quail stuffed with black truffle and foie gras in a millefeuille pastry cup—awakens the senses of the staid villagers in this Oscar-winning Danish drama.

Follow this recipe to discover why. You’ll need a full day to make it, so open a bottle of wine while you’re at it, like Babette.

3. Codornices en salsa de pétalos de rosa from ‘Like Water for Chocolate’ (1992)

More quail (in a sauce of rose petals), but unlike the previous entry, this version evokes a considerably more sensual response from its diners in this Mexican film, which is based on a novel by Laura Esquivel.

The recipe below doesn’t include the crucial ingredient of Tita’s tears, but it’s still likely to inspire a warm glow in your Valentine’s dinner companion.

4. Ramen from ‘Tampopo’ (1987)

Lexus Studios’ Film to Table series found a way to make a version of the perfect bowl of noodles from this Japanese comedy, which Roger Ebert described as “a bemused meditation on human nature in which one humorous situation flows into another offhandedly, as if life were a series of smiles.”

Alton Brown on ‘The Cook, the Thief, His Wife & Her Lover’
The Food Network star explains the most surprising pick in his recent “Food-on-Film” series.outtake.tribecashortlist.com

5. Cubano sandwich from ‘Chef’ (2014)

L.A. celebrity chef Roy Choi created the melty version of the traditional Cubano sandwich that upstages the actors in this gentle foodie comedy.

Director and star Jon Favreau revealed the recipe in a radio interview at the film’s release.

6. Puerco pibil from ‘Once Upon a Time in Mexico’ (2003)

Director Robert Rodriguez’s film—the last of his Mariachi trilogy—isn’t technically a foodie movie, but we’re including this because Rodriguez prides himself on being a great cook (he even cooks for the crew on his films) and made these 10 Minute Cooking School videos as DVD extras for his films, featuring dishes eaten by characters in his movies.

This one features the favorite dish of Agent Sands (Johnny Depp).

(There’s also one in which he shows how to make the famous Tex-Mex breakfast tacos that he cooked for the crew of Sin City, which he co-directed with Frank Miller.)

7. Apple strudel from ‘Inglourious Basterds’ (2009)

Again, not a foodie movie per se, but this crispy cream-laden strudel anchors an excruciating scene between Nazi Col. Hans Landa (Christoph Waltz) and the woman who’s family he unknowingly slaughtered, Shosanna (Mélanie Laurent).

That strudel sure looked tasty, though. Binging With Babish has the recipe.

What’s your favorite dish from a movie? Let us know in the comments or tweet at us @TribecaSL
